Problem:
Consider a system where the function \\( z = x^2 + y^2 \\) models the energy states in a two-dimensional space depending on positions x and y. We explore the effect of a rotational transformation defined by \\( R(\\theta) = \\begin{bmatrix} \\cos(\\theta) & -\\sin(\\theta) \\\\ \\sin(\\theta) & \\cos(\\theta) \\end{bmatrix} \\) applied to a vector \\( v = \\begin{bmatrix} x \\\\ y \\end{bmatrix} \\).

If another transformation \\( S \\), defined by scaling \\( S = \\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 \\\\ 0 & 2 \\end{bmatrix} \\), is applied to \\( v \\) after the initial rotational transformation \\( R(\\theta) \\), will the final energy state \\( z \\) be independent of the angle \\( \\theta \\)?
Explanation: Even after adding a scaling transformation, the final energy state as calculated by  \\( z = x^2 + y^2 \\) will be affected solely by changes in the magnitudes of x and y, regardless of their rotational position. While the scale alters the magnitude, the angle \\( \\theta \\) does not affect the calculation of \\( z \\).
